handDesc.p: Halantas. M seems to be a special form, with a reduced body resembling ma but definitely different from the standard ma in this script, and an extension attached to its top right, which first bends at a soft right angle to the right, then a hard right angle upward, ending in a repha-like curve up and to the right. E.g. l3 pādānudhyātānāM; l22 CHECK DESCRIBE. N in l22 CHECK DESCRIBE.

Other palaeographic observations. Chhabra CHECK, DESCRIBE: unusual medial e, ai and o in l20 s sāhasena, l22 saṁpṛtair and l1 sagotrāṇāṁ. Special subscript l in ll6,16,29. @DABA: subscript l in l6 vallabhendrasya is a simplified spiral continuing to the right in a notched horizontal line, then attached upward to the body of the main consonant. It sort of reminds me of the way halanta consonants are formed in this script, with what could be a halanta l turned 90 degrees to the right. That in l16 guṇakkenallā° is the same. Anusvāra is at headline height to the right of the akṣara to which it belongs, e.g. l1 śrīmatāṁ. It is separated from its akṣara by a line break in l16-17 kuṭu/ṁbinas; Chhabra refers to E Cālukya parallels in IA7 p187 (ll29-30) with remarks on p186; and EI 24 p278 n3.

div.p: Discovered in Cēvūru village in Kaikalūr tāluk of Kistna District in the Madras Presidency, about 1928, by the villager Polavarapu Ankayya, son of Venkata Reddi, who was digging the debris of a collapsed mud house. Seen there by Chhabra in November 1938 and borrowed for study.

Edited from the original by B. Ch. Chhabra (), with translation and inked rubbings supplied by Hultzsch. Chhabra collaborated with N. Laksminarayan Rao for the Telugu part of the inscription. The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on a collation of Chhabra's text with his facsimiles.
